<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_run_noblock:
```c
int metal_run_noblock(int threads, metal_thread_t child,
		     void *arg, void *tids, int *threads_out)
{
	int error, i;
	pthread_t *tid_p = (pthread_t *)tids;

	if (!tids) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "invalid argument, tids is NULL.\n");
		return -EINVAL;
	}

	error = 0;
	for (i = 0; i < threads; i++) {
		error = -pthread_create(&tid_p[i], NULL, child, arg);
		if (error) {
			metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "failed to create thread - %s\n",
				  strerror(error));
			break;
		}
	}

	*threads_out = i;
	return error;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
error = -pthread_create(&tid_p[i], NULL, child, arg);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The fragment does not call any string-handling functions from <string.h>; it only indexes tid_p and calls pthread_create. The loop guard (i < threads) prevents out-of-bounds indexing in normal use, so Rule 21.17 (which concerns functions like memcpy/strcpy/etc.) is not violated. (Note: a separate safety issue could occur if the caller supplies tids that does not point to an array of at least 'threads' pthread_t elements, causing an out-of-bounds access of tid_p[i], but that is not a violation of MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17.)
